title: Palace slams NYT article on Rody
text:
Palace slams NYT article on Rody By Christina Mendez (The Philippine Star)   12:00am 
MANILA, Philippines - Malacañang cried foul over an article in The New York Times that portrayed President Duterte as a leader who rose to popularity because of his profanity and lust for blood. 
Calling it a “well-paid hack job” to serve influential clients with questionable motives, presidential spokesman Ernesto Abella said the article was a form of bullying by the NYT of a president who “does not engage in western liberal niceties to promote his agenda, to rebuild a nation with compromised internal structures.” 
Abella issued the statement the other day as President Duterte capped his official visits yesterday to Myanmar and Thailand, during which he rallied support for the Philippines’ chairmanship of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) this year. 
“One would expect more from The New York Times . Their article, ‘Becoming Duterte: The Making of a Philippine Strongman,’ sounds like a well-paid hack job for well-heeled clients with shady motives,” Abella said. 
In the NYT article datelined Davao City, Duterte was described as a privileged child-turned-populist politician and an anti-drug crusader who has struggled with drug abuse. 
Duterte was also portrayed as “obsessed with death” who turned “his violent vision into national policy.”   
Abella said Duterte should be cited instead for not bowing to Western influence or pressure in leading the country to the path of progress and development. 
He lamented that his critics would rather focus on the more than 7,000 deaths in his war against drugs than on his initiatives like talking peace with Muslim and communist rebels and fighting graft and corruption. 
“He is a rough hewn outsider who vowed to reduce poverty; restore trust in the government by addressing crime, corruption and illegal drugs; and reinforce peace agreements with ethnic Moros who experienced historic injustice, and the CPP/ NPA/ NDF who have been fighting for social justice for decades,” Abella pointed out. 
He said the NYT article “cynically and unfairly narrates the President’s rise to power in the context of violence.” 
“It deliberately fails to mention the many initiatives the President made when he was Davao City mayor,” he said.
